results.title: Microsoft's Cinemania 97 (PC)
results.brief_description: Microsoft Cinemania 97 is an interactive movie guide which has all the latest information about movies and the people involved in making them. There are 20,000 cross-referenced titles with reviews from sources such as ‘Leonard Maltin’s film and video guide’ and biographies of actors, producers directors as well as celebrity guided tours on a range of subjects from Alfred Hitchcok to famous actresses. To use the Apple Macintosh version you will need the following: Multimedia PC with a 486/33MHz processor or higher. Microsoft Windows 95 or Windows NT Workstation operating system 3.1 or later. 8MB of memory for Windows 95, 16MB for Windows NT. 256 colour or higher resolution monitor. Hard disk space not needed to run from CD-ROM but 11MB for best performance.

results.title: Microsecond
results.creator_credit: Dan McLaughlin and S-L Film Productions
results.brief_description: Utilising techniques of time lapse photography - split screen, rapid-fire images and intricate animation effects - to define the concept of a microsecond, this film poses probing questions about time and our relationship to it. It is indicated that 2800 years are to one day what a second is to a microsecond. The 2800 years go by at the rate of twelve still pictures (the art works and artifacts of civilisation) per second. Photo-video: Ralph Sargent. Voice: Loren McLaughlin. Percussion: Jack Eaton.

results.title: Microscopic wonders in water
results.creator_credit: Pat Dowling, Boulton-Hawker Films and Pat Dowling Pictures
results.brief_description: Introduces children to the fascinating world of water life seen through the microscope; shows the use of the microscope and how to prepare cultures. Examples seen include amoeba, vorticella, stentor, urocentrum, rotifer, hydra and the birth and development of a water snail.

results.title: Microscopic life: the world of the invisible
results.creator_credit: Hal Kopel and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: A microscopic study of the beautiful and grotesque animals and plants that can be found in a jar of ordinary pond water. Illustrates and explains the differences between microscopic plants and animals.

results.title: Microscopic fungi
results.creator_credit: J.V. Durden, Hugh O'Connor, Tom Daly and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: A motion picture camera linked to a microscope uncovers a world of fascinating and colorful activity—the world of fungus growth. Highly magnified color cross-sections of vegetable substances attacked by various kinds of fungi give unusually clear illustrations of how these micro-organisms spread and reproduce, and also show their many useful functions.

results.title: Micromotion analysis
results.brief_description: Illustrates the original and then the improved methods for (i) bolt and washer assembly; (ii) burring angle plates; (iii) soldering wire to copper strip; (iv) folding packing papers.

results.title: Micrometer calipers
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic Engineering”.
The principle of the micrometer is explained in detail, its spindle with a thread of a pitch of 1/40th of an inch, the thimble, the adjustable nut and sleeve, the frame and the anvil, graduated line of the sleeve, graduations on the thimble. Stress is laid on the importance of careful maintenance and cleaning, and regular checks for accuracy of this instrument.

results.title: Microcosm
results.creator_credit: Peter Dodds, Ross Campbell and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: A man-made lake is Somers, Victoria, is the setting for a study of bird and insect life in both summer and winter. Debussy’s prelude “a L’Apres-Midi D’Un Faune” accompanies the images. Non-narrated. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Micro-organisms that cause disease
results.brief_description: Five kinds of pathogenic micro-organisms, including fungi, bacteria, viruses, rickettsiae and protozoa. Stresses the concept the pathogenic micro-organisms cause disease through destruction of cells.
